field_edited_text.value:
Policy:
Filling in of the harbor’s water
should be limited.

-

’( ®
Policy:
Enforcement agencies must

aggressively enforce existing laws
prohibiting illegal fill.

Policy:

Where fill is found to be
appropriate, the project sponsor
should create alternate resources in
the harbor.

Harbor filling has long been used as a
way to create real estate. Rather than pur-
chase adjacent property many land owners
simply pushed earth, rubble and wastes
into the harbor. This practice has a number
of negative impacts on the harbor. Filling
decreases the harbor’s ability to absorb pol-
lutants, alters and decreases the tidal flush-
ing ability of the harbor and removes a con-
siderable volume of water where aquatic
habitat could be established. Often, wastes
have leached back into the harbor causing
localized pollution problems. Many fill sites
were not well constructed and have settled
or caused waves of mud generated by the
fill displacing the soft bottom. In all instan-
ces the volume of water in the harbor has
been reduced. Although fill projects were
often small in amount, if all fill projects over
the past 50 years are totalled, several thou-
sands of acres of water have been removed
from the harbor’s system. Every effort
should be made to propose fill which is
only absolutely essential to a projects func-
tion and viability.

Because the harbor has been thought
of as less valuable as an environmental
resource enforcement proceedings against
illegal fill are often given a low priority rel-
ative to more environmentally sensitive
areas of the bay. While this may be justified
to some degree in comparative environ-
mental importance this often relegates the
harbor to simply maintaining the status quo.
Local, State and Federal enforcement agen-
cies must:

1) designate adequate staff for monitoring
and enforcement,

2) assign a high priority to resolving cases
of identified violaters.

There are some projects which may jus-
tify filling of limited areas of the harbor.
Marine terminals and water dependent
industries or industries which have no land-
ward alternative for expansion may qualify
for a permit to fill. These cases are limited
in number, however, and only the actual
area needed will be considered for a per-
mit.

After local, State and Federal agencies
have reviewed and approved a fill project,
there must be some effort to compensate
the harbor’s water system for the lost habi-
tat and resources. This can take the form of
creating wetlands, removing fill from areas
which were once open water, developing
artificial reefs, checking shoreline erosion or
cleaning up a degraded shoreline and open
water area. Alternatives have been clearly
identified in the Baltimore Harbor Environ-
mental Enhancement Plan and must pass
local, State and Federal review.

108







Maryland Port Administration
